thread.title_full: Jessica Chastain treads a wicked path in ‘Crimson Peak’ | Boston Herald

author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Jessica Chastain treads a wicked path in ‘Crimson Peak’
text:
NEW YORK — For Jessica Chastain, “Crimson Peak” (opening Friday) was a mountain she never wants to climb again.
In Guillermo del Toro’s twisted Gothic romance, Chastain plays the rightly named Lady Lucille Sharpe, a severe woman whose harsh demeanor suggests a cat with ready claws.
“It was fun to work with Guillermo, but I really underestimated the toll that this character was going to take on me,” Chastain, 38, told the Herald.
“I was really excited to play Lucille — and I love her when I see the film — but she’s the darkest character I’ve ever played.”
On the set, she asked Tom Hiddleston, who plays Lucille’s younger brother, “I don’t understand. Everyone tells me that playing the villain is the most fun and I’m not having fun.”
The voice of experience — Hiddleston plays Loki in the “Thor” films — replied, “It’s fun when they’re having fun doing what they’re doing.”
That isn’t Lucille.
“It was never, ‘Oh this is a fun, light day!’ Every day was so intense,” the actress recalled.
She felt so drained when “Crimson” wrapped, “I was supposed to go do another film, but I was so depleted I left that film and took time off.”
“Crimson Peak” marks the second time Chastain has worked with del Toro, Mexico’s master of the macabre. He was executive producer on her 2013 horror hit “Mama.”
Before filming “Peak,” del Toro gave each actor a 10-page character biography. It proved an eye-opener for the actress.
“I wanted to understand why she does the things she does, and actually it broke my heart. I found that every (horrible) act she commits is to try to give and to receive love.
“I think the true monsters are her parents. When she was a child, her mother would get beaten by the father, and Lucille was the nursemaid to the father. So taking care of the mother was an act of love associated with suffering.”
Whenever her younger brother did something wrong, “Lucille would take the punishment,” Chastain said.
“That’s why she has scars. So her way of showing love to her brother was to be beaten. Lucille’s always connected love to some kind of pain or suffering, and she can’t quite move through that.”
